body:
Unless you mean something else, I've had this since scrollback was merged:

```
  - { key: PageUp,   mods: Shift,   action: ScrollPageUp                 }
  - { key: PageDown, mods: Shift,   action: ScrollPageDown               }
```

This is documented in the comment above `key_bindings`. (https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/master/alacritty.yml#L369)

Might be a good candidate to add to the default config, though.

Might be worth a quick survey of what other terminals use for defaults with respect to the scrollback buffer. I can test some Linux terminals easily. I'd be curious about macOS and Windows (what other windows terminals are out there worth comparing?).

The primary one for Windows I've heard about is ConEmu, though I'm not familiar with it and its behavior.

The standard behavior seems to be Shift+PageUp/Down in all linux terminal emulators. So I really don't think there's much reason to complicate it. It seemed very standardized to me.

The primary question is if there are scenarios where the escape sequences for Shift+PageUp/Down should still be sent. Looking at the existing terminal emulators it seemed like none of them did anything special and even attempted to scroll in the alt screen buffer. So I think just a simple config file entry should suffice here.
Cool, yea. This is a keybinding I've never used before (been using Alacritty too long :wink:).

issue.title: Alacritty scrolling doesn't work
issue.body:
Which operating system does the issue occur on?

Arch Linux

If on linux, are you using X11 or Wayland?

X11

--

When trying to scroll with alacritty using shift+pageup/pagedown I get `2~2~2~2~` instead, I am not sure if the problem is these keybindings, I am using the default configuration.

alacritty 0.2.7-2 from community Arch Linux repository.

issue.title: Change shift+pgup/pgdown to scroll history
issue.body:
The default shift+pgup/pgdown buttons were sending the escape sequences
specified by the official standard, however most terminal emulators like
XTerm, URxvt and VTE make an exception for this special case and instead
scroll the native history buffer.

Both XTerm and URxvt do never send the escapes for Shift+PgUp/PgDown,
however VTE does send them in the alternate screen.

Since Alacritty already supports keybindings based on terminal mode and
the binding to scroll the history is useless when in the alternate
screen buffer, Alacritty is now following VTEs behavior here, allowing
applications in the alt screen (like vim) to handle this escape.

Fixes #1989.

body: make sure you don't have multiple bindings to scroll and to send chars. The default scrolling bindings `Shift + PageUp/Down` with default config shouldn't send anything. To launch alacritty with default config use `alacritty --config-file /dev/null`.

I also get the `2~2~2~` thing when using the default config.
EDIT: Well apparently just restarting the terminal fixes it. Weeeeeiiiiiiirrrrrddddd.

> Unless you mean something else, I've had this since scrollback was merged:
> 
> ```
>   - { key: PageUp,   mods: Shift,   action: ScrollPageUp                 }
>   - { key: PageDown, mods: Shift,   action: ScrollPageDown               }
> ```
> 
> This is documented in the comment above `key_bindings`. (https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/master/alacritty.yml#L369)
> 
> Might be a good candidate to add to the default config, though.

A similar change doesn't work for me.. 

```
  - { key: PageUp,                    action: ScrollPageUp                 }
  - { key: PageDown,                  action: ScrollPageDown               }
```
